<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-2016_Summer_Olympics skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">2016 Summer Olympics</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"2016 Olympics" redirects here. For the Winter Youth Olympics, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=2016_Winter_Youth_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2016 Winter Youth Olympics (page does not exist)">2016 Winter Youth Olympics</a>.</div>
<div class="dablink">"Rio 2016" redirects here. For the 2016 Paralympic Games, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=2016_Summer_Paralympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2016 Summer Paralympics (page does not exist)">2016 Summer Paralympics</a>.</div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:2016_Summer_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:2016 Summer Olympics (page does not exist)">Template:2016 Summer Olympics</a>
</p><p>The <b>2016 Summer Olympics</b> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i>Jogos Olímpicos de Verão de 2016</i>), officially known as the <b>Games of the XXXI Olympiad</b> (<i>Jogos da XXXI Olimpíada</i>), is a major international <a href="/wiki/Multi-sport_event" title="Multi-sport event">multi-sport event</a> due to be celebrated in the tradition of the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>, as governed by the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC). The host city of the Games will be <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, announced at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=121st_International_Olympic_Committee_Session&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="121st International Olympic Committee Session (page does not exist)">121st</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_IOC_meetings" title="List of IOC meetings">IOC Session</a> held in <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>, on October 2, 2009. They are scheduled to be held from August 5 to 21, 2016, making these the second Summer Olympics to be held during the host city's winter ( the first was the <a href="/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics" title="2000 Summer Olympics">Sydney 2000 Olympics</a>, whose first week was held during the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>'s winter).<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> There will be 35 competition venues mainly in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barra_da_Tijuca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barra da Tijuca (page does not exist)">Barra da Tijuca</a>, but also in three other zones: Copacabana, Deodoro, and Maracanã.
It will mark the first time a <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South American</a> city hosts the event, the third to host in the Southern Hemisphere (and the first time in a Southern Hemisphere country other than Australia), and also the first time a <a href="/wiki/Lusophone" title="Lusophone">Portuguese speaking</a> country hosts the event.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> These will be the first Summer Olympic Games since the Sydney 2000 Olympics not to be held in the host nation's capital city.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bidding_process">Bidding process</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The bidding process for the 2016 Summer Olympic Games was officially launched on May 16, 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> The first step for each city was to submit an initial application to the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) by September 13, 2007, confirming their intention to bid. Completed official bid files, containing answers to a 25-question IOC form, were to be submitted by each applicant city by January 14, 2008. Four candidate cities were chosen for the shortlist on June 4, 2008: <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Madrid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Madrid (page does not exist)">Madrid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> (which hosted the <a href="/wiki/1964_Summer_Olympics" title="1964 Summer Olympics">1964 Summer Olympics</a>). The IOC did not promote <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doha&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doha (page does not exist)">Doha</a> to the Candidature phase, despite scoring higher than selected candidate city Rio de Janeiro, due to their intent of hosting the Olympics in October, outside of the IOC's sporting calendar. <a href="/wiki/Prague" title="Prague">Prague</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a> also failed to make the cut.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nawal_El_Moutawakel" title="Nawal El Moutawakel">Nawal El Moutawakel</a> of Morocco headed the 10 member Evaluation Commission, having also chaired the evaluation commission for the <a href="/wiki/Bids_for_the_2012_Summer_Olympics" title="Bids for the 2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics bids</a>. The commission made on-site inspections in the second quarter of 2009. They issued a comprehensive technical appraisal for IOC members on September 2, one month before elections.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are many restrictions barring the bidding cities from communicating with or influencing directly the 115 voting members. Cities cannot invite any IOC members to visit them and they cannot send them anything that can be construed as a gift. However, bidding cities invest large sums in their PR and media programs in an attempt to indirectly influence the IOC members by garnering domestic support, support from sports media and general international media. Jon Tibbs, a consultant on the Tokyo bid, was recently quoted as saying “Ultimately, you are communicating with just 115 people and each one has influencers and pressure groups but you are still speaking to no more than about 1,500 people, perhaps 5,000 in the broadest sense. It is not just about getting ads out there but it is about a targeted and very carefully planned campaign.”<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>The final voting was held on October 2, 2009, in Copenhagen with Chicago and Rio de Janeiro perceived as favourites to land the games. Chicago and Tokyo were eliminated after the first and second rounds of voting, respectively, while Rio de Janeiro took a significant lead over Madrid heading into the final round. The lead held and Rio de Janeiro was announced as host, becoming the first city in South America to host an Olympic games.
</p>
<center>

</center>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Development_and_preparation">Development and preparation</span></h2>
<p>On June 26, 2011 it was reported on <a href="/w/index.php?title=AroundTheRings.com&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="AroundTheRings.com (page does not exist)">AroundTheRings.com</a> that Roderlei Generali, the COO of the Rio de Janeiro Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games, resigned just one year after taking the job at ROOC. This comes just five months after CCO Flávio Pestana quit for personal reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Pestana withdrew later during the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Paralympics" title="2012 Summer Paralympics">2012 Summer Paralympics</a>. Renato Ciuchin was then appointed as COO.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Venues_and_infrastructure">Venues and infrastructure</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rio_de_Janeiro_bid_venues_for_the_2016_Summer_Olympics.svg" title="File:Rio de Janeiro bid venues for the 2016 Summer Olympics.svg">File:Rio de Janeiro bid venues for the 2016 Summer Olympics.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of Rio de Janeiro showing the competition venues for the 2016 Summer Olympics.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Barra_da_Tijuca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barra da Tijuca (page does not exist)">Barra da Tijuca</a> will host most of the venues of the Olympic and Paralympic Games in 2016. The rest will be located in three other zones: <a href="/wiki/Copacabana_(Rio_de_Janeiro)" title="Copacabana (Rio de Janeiro)">Copacabana Beach</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maracan%C3%A3_(neighborhood)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maracanã (neighborhood) (page does not exist)">Maracanã</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deodoro_Military_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deodoro Military Club (page does not exist)">Deodoro</a>; Barra da Tijuca will also house the Olympic Village.
</p><p>Rio's historical <a href="/w/index.php?title=Centro_(Rio_de_Janeiro)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Centro (Rio de Janeiro) (page does not exist)">downtown</a> is undergoing a large-scale urban waterfront revitalization project called <i>Porto Maravilha</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> It covers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in area. The project aims to redevelop the port area increasing the city center's attractiveness and enhancing Rio’s competitiveness position in the global economy. The urban renovation involves: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of public networks for water supply, sanitation, drainage, electricity, gas and telecom; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of tunnels; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of roads; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of sidewalks; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of bike path; 15,000&#160;trees; three sanitation treatment plants.
</p><p>Besides the <a href="/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_do_Maracan%C3%A3" title="Estádio do Maracanã">Maracanã Stadium</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Est%C3%A1dio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Jo%C3%A3o_Havelange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estádio Olímpico João Havelange (page does not exist)">Engenhão</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> matches will also take place in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salvador,_Bahia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salvador, Bahia (page does not exist)">Salvador</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Arena_Fonte_Nova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arena Fonte Nova (page does not exist)">Arena Fonte Nova</a>), <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a> (<a href="/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_do_Morumbi" title="Estádio do Morumbi">Estádio do Morumbi</a>), <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a> (<a href="/wiki/Mineir%C3%A3o" title="Mineirão">Estádio Mineirão</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Brasília">Brasília</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Est%C3%A1dio_Nacional_de_Bras%C3%ADlia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estádio Nacional de Brasília (page does not exist)">Estádio Nacional de Brasília</a>). All of these stadiums, with the exception of Morumbi, will also be used in the 2014 FIFA World Cup. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arena_Corinthians&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arena Corinthians (page does not exist)">Arena Corinthians</a>, São Paulo's stadium for the World Cup and the opening match's venue, however, is being considered to replace Morumbi in the Olympic Games.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Existing_venues">Existing venues</span></h4>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 475px"><div style="width: 475px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 190px;">Stitched 003.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">

</p>

</ul>

</p>

		</div></li>

</p>

</p>

			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Copacabana_(Rio_de_Janeiro)" title="Copacabana (Rio de Janeiro)">Copacabana Beach</a>, site of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Open_water_swimming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Open water swimming (page does not exist)">open water swimming</a>, <a href="/wiki/Triathlon" title="Triathlon">triathlon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beach_volleyball" title="Beach volleyball">beach volleyball</a>
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Security">Security</span></h3>
<p>Since the award of the 2016 Olympics to Rio de Janeiro, the city's crime problems have received more attention. A police helicopter was shot down over a <a href="/wiki/Favela" title="Favela">favela</a> during one of the city's many drug wars, and the pilot was killed in the incident.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> Rio's mayor has admitted that there are "big issues" facing the city in securing the games from violence. However, he also states that such concerns and issues were presented to the IOC throughout the bidding process.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> The governor of the state of Rio de Janeiro also highlighted the fact that London faced security problems with a <a href="/wiki/7_July_2005_London_bombings" title="7 July 2005 London bombings">terrorist attack</a> occurring on the day following the IOC session that chose the city to host the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Olympic Games</a>.
</p><p>The IOC, however, has expressed optimism with allowing the city and the nation of Brazil to address these concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Seven years is enough time for Rio de Janeiro to clean up its crime problem the IOC says. IOC spokesman Mark Adams told The Associated Press "we have confidence in their capacity to deliver a safe Games in seven years." "Security is of course a very important aspect of any Olympic Games no matter where it is in the world. This is of course entirely under the national, regional and city authorities."<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Luiz_In%C3%A1cio_Lula_da_Silva" title="Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva">Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva</a>, former president of Brazil, has noted that the city has hosted other high-profile events without major incident, for example the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_Pan_American_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 Pan American Games (page does not exist)">2007 Pan American Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rio de Janeiro is planning to pacify local neighbourhoods or <a href="/wiki/Favela" title="Favela">favelas</a>. Community-based Police Pacification Units (UPPs) will be used to combine trust-building in individual communities, through the use of street patrols and civic work.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> Moreover, in the state of Rio de Janeiro, homicides have fallen to the lowest level since 1991, indicating the success of Brazil's "pacification" project implemented for the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 Summer Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-insight_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-insight-20">[20]</a></sup> The Regional Institute of Public Safety reported that the homicide rate of Rio de Janeiro for the first five months of 2012 was at its lowest in the past 21 years, with 10.9 homicides for every 100,000 habitants.<sup id="cite_ref-insight_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-insight-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Nonetheless, despite the decline in homicides and human rights abuses, the <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> urged Brazil to investigate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Extrajudicial_killings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Extrajudicial killings (page does not exist)">extrajudicial killings</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Anti-fraud_plan">Anti-fraud plan</span></h4>
<p>On June 11, 2010, the federal government launched a program to protect the tenders for work in preparation for the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 Olympic Games against the possibility of fraud. The plan, known as <i>Jogando Limpo</i> (<i>Fair Playing</i> or <i>Playing It Clean</i>), includes a series of guidelines and nuggets of advice so that the government institutions, and also the tax authorities and common citizens themselves, may identify and denounce attempts at fraud against the tenders. The program, which was launched by the Ministries of Justice and of Sports, also plans the establishment of a group dedicating to monitoring tenders, to protect them against the threat of fraud and also to avoid delays in construction work.
</p><p>This initiative, also boosted by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Office_of_the_Comptroller_General&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Office of the Comptroller General (page does not exist)">Office of the Comptroller General</a>, also plans a campaign to make the people aware of the need to pay attention to possible fraud and to always denounce such cases. The program emphasizes measures against cartels and possible agreements between competing companies to set prices above market levels, in an attempt to raise the value of the contracts with the state. Minister for Justice Luiz Paulo Barreto lanched the programme in saying: "Nothing can be worse than someone taking advantage of these two great opportunities to commit crimes. This is a world phenomenon. The businesspeople could be entering with an agreement on prices, in order to compete in these tenders. This is something that needs to be tackled. We need to promote fair play also in our tenders. Fair play is something we would expect from a country intending to host events of this size." He added that, between 2007 and 2010, there were a total of 265 search and seizure warrants issued in Brazil to tackle the crime of cartel formation. In the same period over 100 people were preventively arrested for the same crime, and currently an additional 251 people are being investigated.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Games">The Games</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p>There were two open spots for sports and initially seven sports began the bidding for inclusion in the 2016 program. Baseball and <a href="/wiki/Softball" title="Softball">softball</a>, which were dropped from the program in 2005, <a href="/wiki/Karate" title="Karate">karate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Squash_(sport)" title="Squash (sport)">squash</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golf (page does not exist)">golf</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roller_sports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roller sports (page does not exist)">roller sports</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> all applied to be included. Leaders of the seven sports held presentations in front of the IOC executive board in June 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August, the executive board initially gave its approval to <a href="/wiki/Rugby_sevens" title="Rugby sevens">rugby sevens</a> —a seven-man version of rugby union— by a majority vote, thus removing baseball, roller sports, and squash from contention. Among the remaining three —golf, karate, and softball—, the board approved golf as a result of consultation. The final decision regarding the remaining two sports was made on October 9, 2009, the final day of the 121st IOC Session. A new system was in place at this session; a sport now needed only a simple majority from the full IOC committee for approval rather than the two-thirds majority previously required.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> International Golf Federation executive director Antony Scanlon said that the top players, including Tiger Woods and Annika Sörenstam, would show their continued support of golf's Olympic involvement by participating in the events.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p><br />
In May 2012, the <a href="/wiki/International_Sailing_Federation" title="International Sailing Federation">International Sailing Federation</a> announced that <a href="/wiki/Windsurfing" title="Windsurfing">windsurfing</a> would be removed from the 2016 Olympic sailing programme and replaced by <a href="/wiki/Kitesurfing" title="Kitesurfing">kitesurfing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> This decision was reversed in November.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2013, representatives for the IOC announced that the commission would be forced to review the status of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cycling_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics (page does not exist)">cycling events</a> following <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lance_Armstrong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lance Armstrong (page does not exist)">Lance Armstrong</a>'s admission to the use of performance-enhancing drugs amid accusations that senior members of the <a href="/wiki/Union_Cycliste_Internationale" title="Union Cycliste Internationale">Union Cycliste Internationale</a> —the <a href="/wiki/Sport_governing_body" title="Sport governing body">governing body</a> of cycling— had participated in a cover-up of widespread blood doping within the sport.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>In contrast to the exception during the 2012 Olympics, the <a href="/wiki/International_Gymnastics_Federation" title="International Gymnastics Federation" class="mw-redirect">International Gymnastics Federation</a> announced that these Games will have a gala event for gymnastics.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 2016 Summer Olympic programme features 28 sports and a total of 41 disciplines and 306 events.
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-begin (page does not exist)">Template:Col-begin</a>

</p>
<ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Calendar">Calendar</span></h2>
<dl>
<dd><i>All dates are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_in_Brazil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time in Brazil (page does not exist)">Brasília Time</a> (<a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9203:00" title="UTC−03:00">UTC–3</a>)</i>
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:2016_Summer_Olympics_calendar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:2016 Summer Olympics calendar (page does not exist)">Template:2016 Summer Olympics calendar</a>
&lt;/div&gt;
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Logo">Logo</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sculpture_of_the_2016_Summer_Olympics.jpg" title="File:Sculpture of the 2016 Summer Olympics.jpg">File:Sculpture of the 2016 Summer Olympics.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sculpture of the logo</div></div></div>
<p>The Rio 2016 logo was designed by Tatíl Design, a Brazilian company, and unveiled on December 31, 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-adweek_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-adweek-32">[32]</a></sup> The logo represents three figures, in the yellow, green and blue of the Brazilian flag, joined at the arms and in a triple embrace, with the overall shape reflecting that of <a href="/wiki/Sugarloaf_Mountain_(Brazil)" title="Sugarloaf Mountain (Brazil)">Sugarloaf Mountain</a>. The logo was based on four concepts: contagious energy, harmonious diversity, exuberant nature and Olympic spirit. The Rio firm Tatil designed the winning entry for the logo in a competition involving 139 agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/IOC" title="IOC" class="mw-redirect">IOC</a> President <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Rogge" title="Jacques Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a>, the logo really catches the vision of <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> for these Games. The logo has been noted as evoking <a href="/wiki/Henri_Matisse" title="Henri Matisse">Henri Matisse</a>'s painting <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dance_(Matisse)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dance (Matisse) (page does not exist)">Dance</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-logo_factory_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-logo_factory-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Broadcasting">Broadcasting</span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Noflag&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Noflag (page does not exist)">Template:Noflag</a><a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> – <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dentsu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dentsu (page does not exist)">Dentsu</a>; rights in 16 countries in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, to be resold to local broadcasters.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Sweden (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Sweden</a> – <a href="/wiki/Modern_Times_Group" title="Modern Times Group">MTG</a><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data Turkey (page does not exist)">Template:Country data Turkey</a> – <a href="/w/index.php?title=FOX_(Turkey)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FOX (Turkey) (page does not exist)">FOX</a><sup id="cite_ref-sportfive_48-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sportfive-48">[48]</a></sup>
</li>
